document_metadata.name: Neural Systems Governed by Nicotinic Acetylcholine Receptors: Emerging Hypotheses

nodes.name: Autosomal Dominant Nocturnal Frontal Lobe Epilepsy

links.evidence: In 2011, we know that cholinergic actions in the brain govern various processes: cognition (attention and executive function) (Couey et al., 2007; Levin and Rezvani, 2007; Heath and Picciotto, 2009; Howe et al., 2010), learning and memory (Gould, 2006; Couey et al., 2007; Levin and Rezvani, 2007), mood (anxiety, depression) (Picciotto et al., 2008), reward (addiction, craving) (Tang and Dani, 2009), and sensory processing (Heath and Picciotto, 2009)

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: While genetic linkages of lynx family members to neurological disorders have not been found, evidence for cholinergic dysregulation has been linked to a lynx family member expressed in nonneuronal tissues and involved in human disease (Chimienti et al., 2003), and as such, alterations in lynx dosage may be useful in ameliorating cognitive decline associated with neuropsychiatric disorders.

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Most brain HS nAChRs reside on presynaptic terminals, where they stimulate neurotransmitter release (Gotti et al., 2006; Albuquerque et al., 2009)

links.evidence: As GPI-anchored proteins can bind to transmembrane receptors intracellularly, the interactions of lynx with nAChRs could potentially alter receptor trafficking, stoichiometry, and surface number (Lester et al., 2009)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Abolishing receptor function through null mutations or pharmacological blockers of nAChRs abolished some of the gain-offunction phenotypes in lynx mouse models, indicating that nAChRs are necessary for the expression of lynx perturbations (Miwa et al., 2006)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Because excess activation of nAChRs damages neuronal health and brain function, organisms have a clear need to restrict the degree of nAChR activation

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Nicotinic receptor control over GABAergic neuronal development and mature activity may represent a point of convergence for diseases such as schizophrenia (see next section), some amblyopias (Bavelier et al., 2010), and some epilepsies (Klaassen et al., 2006), which distort the excitatory-inhibitory balance in general and implicate GABAergic signaling defects in particular

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Developmental changes in nAChR functions may play a role in nicotine addiction, as a central question in tobacco control is young adult smokersâ marked sensitivity to developing nicotine dependence (DSM-V Nicotine Workgroup, 2010; DiFranza et al., 2000; Difranza, 2010)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Recent studies provide evidence both that nicotinic signaling partially underlies these schizophrenia-related inhibitory defects and that nicotinic drugs have possible therapeutic roles

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Nicotinic activation of inhibitory interneurons increases their activity and activates nitric oxide synthetase

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: A major subtype in the brain is alpha4beta2; the (alpha42beta23) stoichiometry exhibits at least 10-fold-higher sensitivity than (alpha43beta22), so that only the former has the high sensitivity (HS) that allows activation at nicotine concentrations in the 0.1â1 mM range, produced by moderate tobacco use and by the various nicotine replacement therapies

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: alpha7 nAChRs also respond to nicotine concentrations roughly an order of magnitude higher than alpha42beta23, and alpha7 nAChRs have high Ca2+ permeability resembling that of NMDA receptors

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: While it is not yet possible to know precisely how well a7 nAChRs are activated by smoked nicotine, one can reasonably hypothesize that the patientsâ higher dose of nicotine activates alpha7 nAChRs (Adler et al., 1993; Papke and Thinschmidt, 1998; Royal College of Physicians, 2007)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Evidence thus far indicates that the lynx family is regulated in response to relatively strong perturbations: downregulation in NKCC1 knockout mice (Pfeffer et al., 2009), in adenylyl cyclase mutant mice (Wieczorek et al., 2010), and by alpha7 nAChR blockade (Hruska et al., 2009), whereas it is upregulated at the close of the critical period in the visual cortex, and by nicotine in the lung (Sekhon et al., 2005)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Nicotine both activates and desensitizes nAChRs in midbrain dopaminergic neurons (Brodie, 1991; Pidoplichko et al., 1997), and the pleasurable effects associated with nicotine intake occur in large part via the mesolimbic dopaminergic reward system (Corrigall et al., 1992; Koob and Volkow,2010)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: This puzzle does not yet have a complete answer, but it is clear that chronic nicotine increases the number of nAChRs themselves (Marks et al., 1983; Schwartz and Kellar, 1983)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: At the level of whole brain, chronic nicotine causes selective upregulation of nAChRs among major brain regions. Upregulation occurs in cortex, midbrain, and hypothalamus, but not in thalamus or cerebellum (Pauly et al., 1991; Marks et al., 1992; Nguyen et al., 2003; Nashmi et al., 2007; Doura et al., 2008)

links.evidence: However, it is not known whether the nicotine-enhanced cognitive performance exceeds the level that would occur if the person had never begun to smoke, or after remaining abstinent for one year (the usual criterion for successful smoking cessation) (Levin et al., 2006)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Chronic or acute nicotine enhances LTP in several regions of hippocampus, especially dentate gyrus (Nashmi et al., 2007; TangandDani, 2009;Pentonet al., 2011)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Chronic nicotine upregulates alpha4* nAChRs in dopaminergic presynaptic terminals, apparently leading to increased resting dopamine release from those terminals

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: In the medial perforant path, which mainly arises from layer II stellate cells, chronic nicotine upregulates alpha4beta2* nAChRs

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: In midbrain, chronic nicotine treatment elicits a general increase in alpha4beta2* nAChRs in GABAergic neurons, but only in axon terminals of DA neurons

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Because alpha4beta2 nAChRs are the most susceptible to nicotine-induced upregulation, the data again seem consistent with the idea that selective upregulation of alpha4beta2 nAChRs underlies nicotine dependence

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: The upregulation of alpha4beta2* nAChRs by chronic nicotine treatment has been replicated many times in numerous systemsâtransfected cell lines, neurons in culture, brain slices, and smokersâ brains (Albuquerque et al., 2009; Fu et al., 2009; Lester et al., 2009; Srinivasan et al., 2011

citation.name: Neuron

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: While chronic nicotine does not change the abundance or function of alpha4* nAChRs in the somata of substantia nigra pars compacta dopaminergic neurons, it does suppress baseline firing rates of these DA neurons.

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: These contrasting effects on GABA and DA neurons are due to upregulated alpha4* nAChR responses in GABA neurons, at both somata and synaptic terminals

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: The chaperoning of nAChRs by nicotine enhances the export of alpha4beta2 nAChRs from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), and this leads to a general increase in ER exit sites (Srinivasan et al., 2011)

links.evidence: While chronic nicotine does not change the abundance or function of alpha4* nAChRs in the somata of substantia nigra pars compacta dopaminergic neurons, it does suppress baseline firing rates of these DA neurons.

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: In mice exposed to chronic nicotine, GABA neurons in substantia nigra pars reticulata have increased baseline firing rates, both in brain slices and in anesthetized animals

citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: ADNFLE patients who use a nicotine patch or tobacco have fewer seizures (Willoughby et al., 2003; Brodtkorb and Picard, 2006)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Although alpha7 nAChRs have both presynaptic and postsynaptic expression (Frazier et al., 1998), their postsynaptic expression in humans is especially marked on inhibitory neurons of the hippocampus (Alkondon et al., 2000)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: First, postmortem studies of the hippocampus and thalamus show diminished labeling of putative inhibitory neurons by alpha-bungarotoxin, an antagonist of alpha7 nAChRs (Court et al., 1999)

links.evidence: The ââvolume transmissionââ hypothesis states that ACh released from presynaptic terminals spreads to more distant areas, reaching concentrations < 1 mM (Descarries et al., 1997), but that multiple presynaptic impulses produce enough summed release to activate receptors (Lester, 2004)

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: In most regions that receive cholinergic innervation, the high density of acetylcholinesterase (which can hydrolyze ACh at a rate of one per 100 ms!) might vitiate the volume transmission mechanism

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Indeed, cholinergic enhancement (via cholinesterase inhibition) reopens the critical period for visual acuity in adult wild-type mice (Morishita et al., 2010), indicating that cellular mechanisms for robust plasticity are maintained in adulthood through the cholinergic system but are suppressed by the action of lynx.

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: As we will see below, the mystery of somatodendritic nAChRs can also be resolved by the sensitivity of alpha7 nAChRs to constant levels of another agonist, choline

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.

links.evidence: Mutations in nicotinic receptor subunits are linked to human disease, alpha4 and beta2 in some epilepsies, alpha7 in schizophrenia, and alpha5 in nicotine addiction; and each mutation ultimately manifests itself as an imbalance in the properties of neuronal circuits

citation.name: Neuron
citation.title: Neural systems governed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors: emerging hypotheses.
